question: The working-age population is the total number of people

options.answer: in the labour force who are employed.
in the labour force, aged 15 years and over.
in the labour force, aged 15 years and over, and employed.

question: Which one of the following people would be counted as unemployed in Canada?

options.answer: Veena is not working, but she is looking for a full-time job.
Kathy has stopped looking for work since she was unable to find a suitable job during a one-month search.
Sharon is a college student with a job.
Christos has been laid off from his job a month ago, and has not been looking for a new job as he is waiting for a severance package from his former employer.
Benoit who was laid off when his firm closed down 2 months ago and has not been looking for work as he is going back to school.

question: Which one of the following people would be counted as unemployed in Canada?

options.answer: Doris works only 5 hours a week but is looking for a full-time job.
Kanhaya has stopped looking for work since he was unable to find a suitable job during a two-month search.
Sharon recently began looking for work after staying at home for 10 years to look after her children.
Maurice is on a 2 month vacation out of the country but is still looking for a job using the internet.

question: Which one of the following people would be counted as unemployed in Canada?

options.answer: Simone is currently working but expects to be laid off by the end of the month, before next month's survey can be completed.
Ruth is a 14-year-old student and has been looking for an after-school job every day for the past month.
Sarah has been looking for a job but is taking a month-long break from the job-seeking effort due to her lack of skills.
Rebekah is a recent graduate looking for work.
Ron has quit looking because he believes that there is no work available for him.

question: Which one of the following people would be counted as unemployed in Canada?

options.answer: a part-time worker who repeatedly expresses a desire to become a full-time worker
a person who has been seeking a job for the last six months, but recently gave up looking because he was discouraged by his job prospects
a person who will be starting a new job in 6 months
a person who expects to be laid off by the end of the month before next month's survey can be completed
a person who has been laid off for 10 weeks and is not looking for a job because he is waiting to be called back to his old job

question: The labour force is

options.answer: the total number of people employed.
the total number of people aged 15 years and over.
the total number of people in the working-age population who are employed.
the total number of people in the working-age population who are either employed or unemployed.

question: The unemployment rate is defined as the number of

options.answer: unemployed people divided by the number of employed people.
employed people divided by the number of people in the country.
unemployed people divided by the number of people in the country.
unemployed people divided by the sum of the people employed and the people unemployed.
unemployed people divided by the number of people in the country who are employed.

question: Counting involuntary part-time workers as unemployed would

options.answer: not change the actual unemployment rate.

question: Who of the following would be counted as unemployed in Canada?

options.answer: Doris only works five hours a week but is looking for a full-time job.
Kanhaya has stopped looking for work since he was unable to find a suitable job during a two-month search.
Sharon is a college student with no job.
Maurice has been laid off from his job for 20 weeks but expects to be called back soon.
Bogdan has been laid off from his job but does not expect to be called back, and is not looking.

question: Who of the following would be counted as unemployed in Canada?

options.answer: Caitlin, who is 14 years old, and looking for a babysitting job.
James, who is a full-time student looking for a part-time job.
Youngmin, who is a part-time hamburger flipper looking for a full-time job.
Emmanuel, who lost his job at the steel plant when an automated assembly line was introduced six months ago, and has been job searching every day.
Vik, who has been staying at home watching "The Old and the Boring" soap opera, and not searching since he was laid off at the flour mill.

question: If the working-age population increases, then

options.answer: the size of the labour force will increase.
the number of people employed will increase.
the labour force participation rate will increase.
the total number of people aged 15 years and above will increase.

In a country with a working-age population of 20 million, 13 million are employed, 1.5 million are unemployed, and 1 million of the employed are working part-time, half of whom wish to work full-time. The labour force participation rate is

In a country with a working-age population of 22 million, 16 million are employed, 2 million are unemployed, and 1 million of the employed are working part-time, half of whom wish to work full-time. The employment-to-population ratio is

In a country with a working-age population of 22 million, 16 million are employed, 2 million are unemployed, and 1 million of the employed are working part-time, half of whom wish to work full-time. The involuntary part-time rate is

In a country with a working-age population of 30 million, 18 million are employed, 2 million are unemployed, and 2 million of the employed are working part-time, half of whom wish to work full-time. The labour force is

In a country with a working-age population of 30 million, 18 million are employed, 2 million are unemployed, and 2 million of the employed are working part-time, half of whom wish to work full-time. The labour force participation rate is

In a country with a working-age population of 30 million, 18 million are employed, 2 million are unemployed, and 2 million of the employed are working part-time, half of whom wish to work full-time. The unemployment rate is

In a country with a working-age population of 30 million, 18 million are employed, 2 million are unemployed, and 2 million of the employed are working part-time, half of whom wish to work full-time. The employment-to-population ratio is

In a country with a working-age population of 30 million, 18 million are employed, 2 million are unemployed, and 2 million of the employed are working part-time, half of whom wish to work full-time. The involuntary part-time rate is
Which of the following reflects an increase in unemployment?

options.answer: an increase in the employment-to-population ratio
a decrease in the unemployment rate
an increase in the labour force participation rate
an increase in the involuntary part-time rate

question: The labour force participation rate is

options.answer: the percentage of the working-age population who are employed.
the percentage of the labour force who are unemployed or employed.
the percentage of the working-age population who are either unemployed or employed.
the percentage of the labour force who are employed.

question: The employment-to-population ratio is

options.answer: the percentage of the working-age population who are employed.
the percentage of the labour force who are unemployed or employed.
the percentage of the working-age population who are unemployed or employed.
the percentage of the labour force who are employed.

question: In a recession, typically

options.answer: the labour force participation rate rises.
both A and B are correct.

question: In a recession, typically

options.answer: the labour force participation rate increases.

question: Complete the following sentence. In an expansion, typically

options.answer: the labour force participation rate increases.
both B and D are correct.

question:
Which of the following pieces of information do you need to calculate the labour force participation rate?
I.	the number of employed persons
II.	the number of unemployed persons
III.	the population
IV.	the working age population
Since 1960, Canadian labour force participation rate has ________ and the unemployment rate has ________.

options.answer: trended lower; varied over the business cycle
varied over the business cycle; trended higher
trended higher; varied over the business cycle

question: If the people who take early retirement are not counted in the working-age population, then

options.answer: the unemployment rate would be lower.
the labour force participation rate would be less.
the unemployment rate would be higher.
the labour force participation rate would be higher.

question: If the labour force participation rate is rising and the working-age population is not changing, then the

options.answer: size of the labour force is rising.
number of unemployed people is rising and the size of the labour force is falling.
size of the labour force is falling.
number of unemployed people is falling and the size of the labour force is rising.
number of employed people must be increasing.

question: The working-age population can be divided into two groups:

options.answer: those who are employed and those who are unemployed.
those in the labour force and discouraged workers.
those who work full time and those who work part time.
those in the labour force and those not in the labour force.
those who are over the age of 15 and those who are under the age of 15.

question: Which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.answer: The labour force is equal to the number of people employed plus the number of people unemployed.
The unemployment rate is the number of persons who are unemployed divided by the labour force, all multiplied by 100.
The labour-force participation rate is the labour force divided by the working-age population, all multiplied by 100.
The employment-to-population ratio is the number of people employed divided by the working-age population, all multiplied by 100.
The involuntary part-time rate is the number of involuntary part-time workers divided by the number employed, all multiplied by 100.

question: Which of the following is NOT included in the working-age population?

options.answer: All of the above are included in the working-age population.

question: Suppose the working-age population in Tiny Town is 100 people. If 25 of these people are not in the labour force, the ________ equals ________.

In a country with a working-age population of 22 million, 16 million are employed, 2 million are unemployed, and 1 million of the employed are working part-time, half of whom wish to work full-time. If 500,000 of those unemployed are cyclically unemployed, what is the natural unemployment rate?

In a country with a working-age population of 30 million, 18 million are employed, 2 million are unemployed, and 2 million of the employed are working part-time, half of whom wish to work full-time. If 1 million of those unemployed are cyclically unemployed, what is the natural unemployment rate?
Which one of the following people is structurally unemployed?

options.answer: a Saskatchewan welder who lost her job when her company relocated to B. C. and is currently looking for a job
a Nova Scotia fishery worker who is searching for a better job closer to home
a steel worker who is laid off but who expects to be called back soon
an office worker who has lost her job because of a general slowdown in economic activity

question: Unemployment caused by permanently decreased demand for horse-drawn carriages is an example of
Which one of the following people is cyclically unemployed?

options.answer: a Saskatchewan welder who lost her job when her company relocated to B. C. and is currently looking for a job
a Nova Scotia fishery worker who is searching for a better job closer to home
a steel worker who is laid off but who expects to be called back soon
an office worker who has lost her job because of a general slowdown in economic activity

question: Which one of the following people is frictionally unemployed? A steel worker who

options.answer: loses her job because of technological change.
is laid off but expects to be called back soon.
gives up her job because she retires.
decides to leave the labour force and become a full-time ballet student.
becomes discouraged and stops looking for a job.

question: If the economy is at full employment, then

options.answer: the entire labour force is employed.
the only unemployment is frictional unemployment plus discouraged workers.
the unemployment rate is less than 3 percent.
all unemployment arises from normal frictions and structural change.

question: The natural unemployment rate is

options.answer: the same as the cyclical unemployment rate.
the rate at which cyclical unemployment is equal to 6 percent.
the rate at which cyclical unemployment is equal to 0 percent.

question: At full employment, there is no
A zero percent unemployment rate

options.answer: is one of the economic goals of the Canadian government.
is not consistent with the notion of full employment.
was last achieved during World War II when everyone was willing to work at the going wage rate to end the war.
is the only efficient unemployment rate.

question: Complete the following sentence. Full employment

options.answer: occurs when all unemployment is cyclical and structural.
occurs when all unemployment is frictional and discouraged.
occurs when there is zero unemployment.
occurs when there is zero frictional unemployment.
occurs when there is zero cyclical unemployment.

question: In Table 21.2.1, which person is frictionally unemployed?
In Table 21.2.1, which person is structurally unemployed?
In Table 21.2.1, which person is cyclically unemployed?
In Table 21.2.1, which person is a discouraged worker?
Structural unemployment arises in part because

options.answer: there are not enough jobs available.
people become discouraged when they cannot find jobs.
people will not quit their present jobs until they can find suitable employment elsewhere.

question: Full employment does not mean that there is zero unemployment because

options.answer: some cyclical unemployment is always present.
some frictional and structural unemployment is always present.
of the existence of discouraged workers.

question: In a dynamic economy under ideal conditions, the unemployment rate

options.answer: is greater than zero percent due to natural unemployment.
increases as the price level rises.
decreases as the price level falls.

question: If the economy is operating at full employment, then

options.answer: everyone who wants a job has one.
the entire labour force is employed.
the unemployment rate is approximately 3 percent.

question: Jesse just graduated from university, and is looking for her first job. Jesse is
Caitlin is working part-time at the Mr. G store, but wants to work full-time. She is
Michael lost his job as a night security guard because he kept falling asleep at the job. Now he is looking for a new job. Michael is
Rochelle lost her job as a salesperson when sales fell off during the recession. Now she is looking for a new job. Rochelle is
Henelyn lost her job as a factory worker when she was replaced by a robotic machine. Now she is looking for a new job. Henelyn is
People become unemployed when they

options.answer: quit working to go to university.
leave university and start seeking work.

question: People end unemployment when they

options.answer: quit work to go to school.
quit work to raise a family.

question: Counting discouraged workers as unemployed would

options.answer: not change the measured unemployment rate.

question: If the number of discouraged workers increases, everything else remaining the same, then the

options.answer: labour force participation rate will increase.
labour force participation rate will decrease.

question: If the number of discouraged workers decreases because many of them start to look for work, everything else remaining the same, then the

options.answer: labour force participation rate will increase.
labour force participation rate will decrease.

question: Suppose the economy is experiencing frictional unemployment of 1 percent, structural unemployment of 3 percent and cyclical unemployment of 4 percent. What is the natural unemployment rate?
Suppose that the natural unemployment rate is 4.5 percent and the actual unemployment rate is 3.5 percent. Then cyclical unemployment is
Suppose that the unemployment rate equals 4.5 percent and that the natural unemployment rate is 5.5 percent. We can conclude that

options.answer: potential GDP is greater than real GDP.
potential GDP is less than real GDP.
we have mismeasured the natural unemployment rate.
real GDP is greater than nominal GDP.

question: If the economy is at full employment,

options.answer: the entire labour force is employed.
the only unemployment is frictional unemployment plus discouraged workers.
all unemployment is cyclical and structural.

question: When the unemployment rate is less than the natural unemployment rate, real GDP is ________ than potential GDP and the output gap is ________.
When the unemployment rate ________ the natural unemployment rate, real GDP ________ potential GDP.

options.answer: is greater than; is less than
is less than; is less than

question: Some unemployment is unavoidable because ________.

options.answer: people are making transitions through the stages of life and businesses are making transitions
many part-time workers would like to have full-time work
many people in the working-age population attend school and are unemployed
there is always some cyclical unemployment

question: The official unemployment rate might underestimate the underutilization of labour resources for all of the following reasons except ________.

options.answer: it excludes part-time workers who want full-time jobs
it excludes people who are waiting to be called back to jobs from which they have been laid off
the official unemployment rate excludes all of the above

question: The unemployment rate is supposed to measure ________. It is an imperfect measure because ________.

options.answer: the number of unemployed plus the number of marginally attached workers expressed as a percentage of the labour force; it excludes the marginally attached workers because Statistics Canada considers them as employed
the percentage of the working-age population who are unemployed; it is impossible to count everyone in the working-age population
the percentage of the labour force who are unemployed; it is impossible to count everyone in the labour force
the underutilization of labour resources; it excludes some underutilized labour and some unemployment is unavoidable
the underutilization of labour resources; it includes part-time workers and excludes discouraged workers

question: The three types of unemployment are

options.answer: cyclical, maternity leave, and paternity leave.

question: Frictional unemployment ________.

options.answer: includes workers who have lost their jobs due to an economic downturn
is unemployment associated with normal labour turnover
occurs when changes in technology change the skills needed to perform jobs

question: Suppose the country of Tiny Town experiences frictional unemployment. This frictional unemployment would

options.answer: signal that the country is in a recession.
be considered a natural occurrence in a growing economy.
signal the number of discouraged workers is growing.

if the price of a good was $100 in 2002, its price in 2012 is $122.
prices of consumer goods have more than doubled.
the market basket of consumer goods that cost $122 in 2002 can be purchased for $100 in 2012.
the average of the prices paid by urban consumers for a fixed market basket of consumer goods and services was 22 percent higher in 2012 than it was on average during 2002.

question: The consumer price index is a measure of

options.answer: the average of the prices paid by urban consumers for a fixed basket of consumer goods and services.
the commodity prices paid by urban consumers for a fixed basket of consumer goods and services.

options.answer: the annual change in the price level.
the annual percentage change in the price level.

It costs 158 times more in 2012 than it does in 2002 to buy the same market basket.
All prices have risen by the same amount.
The inflation rate in 2012 is greater than the inflation rate in 2002.
The inflation rate in 2002 is greater than the inflation rate in 2012.

question: The fixed basket of Econoland consists of 10 units of A, 20 units of B, and 30 units of C. Current prices are $1 per unit of A, $2 per unit of B, and $3 per unit of C. Base year prices are $1 for each unit of A, B, and C. What is the CPI in the current year?

topic.name: The Price Level, Inflation, and Deflation

question: The Consumer Price Index measures inflation by using

options.answer: all goods and services that are produced using a current-year basket.
all goods and services that are produced using a base-year basket.
only consumption goods and services purchased using a current-year basket.
only consumption goods and services purchased using a base-year basket.

topic.name: The Price Level, Inflation, and Deflation

question: The technique used to calculate the CPI implicitly assumes that consumers buy

options.answer: relatively more of goods with relative prices that are increasing.
relatively less of goods with relative prices that are decreasing.
the same relative quantities of goods as in a base year.
goods and services whose quality improves at the rate of growth of real GDP.
more computers and CD players and fewer black-and-white TVs.

topic.name: The Price Level, Inflation, and Deflation

question: If there is a 5 percent increase in the CPI, then there will most likely be

options.answer: a 5 percent rise in the cost of living.
a less than 5 percent rise in the cost of living because of consumers substituting away from goods whose relative prices rise towards other goods.
a more than 5 percent rise in the cost of living because of consumers substituting away from goods whose relative prices rise towards other goods.
a less than 5 percent rise in the cost of living because of falling quality of goods over time.
a more than 5 percent rise in the cost of living because of the introduction of new goods.

topic.name: The Price Level, Inflation, and Deflation

question: All of the following are possible sources of bias in using the Consumer Price Index to measure inflation except

options.answer: an improvement in the quality of goods.
an increase in the cost of living
Both C and D are exceptions.

question: Suppose a trade union and a firm agree to increase the wage rate by the same percentage as the increase in the Consumer Price Index. If the CPI increases by 5 percent, then the real income of workers will

options.answer: remain unchanged, accounting for bias in the calculation of the CPI.
decrease by 5 percent, accounting for bias in the calculation of the CPI.
increase by more than 5 percent, accounting for bias in the calculation of the CPI.
increase by less than 5 percent, accounting for bias in the calculation of the CPI.

question: Comparing the core inflation rate to the Consumer Price Index, the core inflation rate

options.answer: controls for the biases of the CPI.
measures all goods produced, not just consumer goods.
uses current period quantities, not base period quantities.
excludes the volatile elements of the CPI.
includes volatile elements not in the CPI.

question: If the inflation rate is positive, the price level in an economy is

topic.name: The Price Level, Inflation, and Deflation

question: Commodity substitution bias in the CPI refers to the fact that the CPI

options.answer: takes into account the substitution of goods by consumers when relative prices change.
takes no account of the substitution of goods by consumers when relative prices change.
substitutes quality changes whenever they occur without taking account of the cost of the quality changes.
substitutes relative prices for absolute prices of goods.
accounts for improved quality in price rises.

topic.name: The Price Level, Inflation, and Deflation

question: Of the following sequences of price levels, which correctly represents a 5 percent inflation rate?

topic.name: The Price Level, Inflation, and Deflation

question: The commodity substitution bias is that

options.answer: consumers substitute high-quality goods for low-quality goods.
government spending is a good substitute for investment expenditures.
national saving and foreign borrowing are interchangeable.
consumers decrease the quantity they buy of goods whose relative prices rise and increase the quantity of goods whose relative price falls.
consumers substitute more expensive goods for less expensive goods when technology advances.

topic.name: The Price Level, Inflation, and Deflation

question: Hyperinflation is defined as

options.answer: an increase in the price level.

topic.name: The Price Level, Inflation, and Deflation

question: Choose the incorrect statement.

options.answer: The outlet substitution bias injects an upward bias into the CPI.
When the quality of a good improves over time and as a result the price rises, the CPI counts the entire price rise as inflation and so overstates inflation.
When relative prices change and people substitute to the lower priced good, the CPI ignores the substitution and the CPI overstates inflation.
The CPI basket is constantly updated to allow for the introduction of new goods.
All of the above statements are incorrect.

topic.name: The Price Level, Inflation, and Deflation

question: The price indexes that are alternatives to the CPI are ________.

options.answer: the GDP deflator and the chained price index for consumption
the chained price index for consumption and the CPI deflator
the core GDP deflator and the CPI deflator
the GDP deflator and the CPI deflator
the unbiased CPI and the unbiased GDP deflator

topic.name: The Price Level, Inflation, and Deflation

question: The CPIC ________.

options.answer: does not overcome the source of bias in the CPI
overcomes the sources of bias in the CPI by eliminating measures of the goods and services with the most volatile prices
overcomes the sources of bias in the CPI by incorporating substitutions and using current and previous period quantities
overcomes the sources of bias in the CPI by giving extra weight to the measures of the goods and services with the most volatile prices
overcomes the sources of bias in the CPI by always using discount store prices

topic.name: The Price Level, Inflation, and Deflation

question: Refer to Table 21.3.3. The IMF World Economic Outlook reports the price level data given in the table. The region with the highest inflation rate in 2007 is ________. The region with the highest inflation rate in 2008 is ________.

options.answer: the Euro area; the United States
the United States; the Euro area

question: Between 1972 and 2012, Canada's inflation rate as measured by the CPI ________.

options.answer: rises in some years and falls in some years
was always between 1 and 3 percent a year

question: In China, suppose that the price level was 100 in 2007, 110 in 2008, 120 in 2009, and 130 in 2011. Over this time period,

options.answer: Both C and D are correct.

question: If the inflation rate is negative, the price level in an economy is ________.
